awd_titl_txt: Tough as Nails, Nimble Fingers: Developing a K-8 Coding Pathway for Kentucky Appalachia
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of the "Tough as Nails, Nimble Fingers Research Practitioner Partnership (RPP)" is to develop a pipeline for computer science (CS) and computational thinking (CT) education within Pikeville Independent Schools and Floyd County K-8 schools.  Kentucky Appalachia K-8 instructors will learn the basics of CS and CT and how to integrate these skills and concepts into existing coursework.  Through the professional development and curricular model of South Fayette School District (a national leader in CS/CT education) and wider support from local company Bit Source, Pikeville Independent School district and Floyd County schools will develop their own CS/CT pathways, grounding coursework and learning competencies in the educational and economic needs of their respective communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
Tough as Nails, Nimble Fingers: Developing a K-8 Coding Pathway for Kentucky Appalachia established a transformative research-practice partnership that continues to enhance K-8 education in Eastern Kentucky. Grounded in the aspirations and ingenuity of a pair of rural school districts, the project achieved significant outcomes in both research and practice.

Intellectual Merit

The project produced significant intellectual contributions to understanding culturally responsive and rurally sustaining computational thinking (CT) education, especially around what it takes to create and sustain a locally relevant CT Pathway in a rural and economically challenged area like Eastern Kentucky. Through research, practice, and reflection, the project identified important elements for sustaining CT pathways (Dunbar, Coenraad & Iwatani, 2024), such as connecting CT education to rural communities’ socioeconomic priorities and aspirations for future economic possibilities, and connecting CT to rural communities’ cultural wealth (Yosso, 2005).

The project also identified the importance of positioning complex problem solving (Döner & Funke, 2017) a key focus of rural CT education. Education and workforce leaders in Eastern Kentucky emphasized the need for students to develop the ability to solve complex, open-ended problems, contributing to workforce revitalization and preparing for future roles, including those in "jobs that don’t exist yet." The two districts’ commitment to CT within their contexts suggests that rural CT education should foreground complex problem solving, and emphasize CT as tools to supplement their problem-solving toolkit, to address a range of community priorities (Iwatani, Coenraad & Dunbar, 2024). Community leaders encouraged further exploration of connections between problem solving, Appalachian ingenuity and computational thinking, which has led to a second collaboration grant (https://www.nsf.gov/awardsearch/showAward?AWD_ID=2219401).  

Finally, the project found how rurally sustaining CT pathways requires robust cross-culture, cross-sector, and insider-outsider partnerships. These collaborations are important in resource-constrained rural areas, where pooling expertise and fostering shared understanding can drive innovation. A sustained reflection on this project (Coenraad et. al, in press) highlighted the importance of continuous trust-building, cultural sensitivity, and adaptability within these partnerships. Rural cultures and the cultures of CS/CT often have distinct historical roots, making it essential to bridge these perspectives effectively.  

Broader Impacts

Over the course of the five years (2019-2024), including the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, the project trained 259 educators from Kentucky Appalachia in K-8 computational thinking rationale, strategies, and classroom activities. Through this teacher training, coupled with other strategic initiatives described below, the project successfully established CT pathways that now serve a significant number of students.  Specifically, the research-practice partnership achieved: 

1. A consistent, cumulative course-of-study (pathway) in CT across five K-8 schools, and emerging pathways in the remaining five

2. In SY 2023-24 alone, at least 1,991 (45%) of K-8 students received over 10 hours of instruction in data practices and/or algorithms, across both districts.  

Alongside establishing CT pathways, the project succeeded in establishing and evolving its summer teacher training program “Eastern Kentucky STEAM Innovation Summer Institute” driven by the two districts as emerging regional leaders in CT education. While the 2020 summer institute courses assumed no prior background in STEAM/ CT and involved no community speakers, by 2024, there were three strands of trainings based on varying levels of local educator proficiency, a full-day field trip for everyone, and an additional 240 minutes of engagement with community members about local innovations. In 2020, all of the training was delivered by instructors and researchers who were from outside of Eastern Kentucky. By 2024, most of the training was delivered by Eastern KY educators, all of whom were trained through the prior Summer Institutes. 

Key to these high-level accomplishments were numerous intermediary activities and accomplishments, established through close collaborations between teachers, researchers and broader community members. These include but are not limited to: 

  • An operational definition of computational thinking competencies that aligns with district instructional aspirations and KY standards, and is strategically distinguished from domain-general goals such as deeper learning. 

  • CSforAll vision and mission statements, and curriculum pathway documents for each district, and reported progress by educators, even 1-3 years post-training. 

  • Consistent buy-in among educators to programmatic implementation of CT, even after 1-3 years after their direct involvement in the training. 

  • Substantial increases in teacher comfort and confidence in CT as both a concept and contextual practice, and reduction in perceived barriers, in ably teaching it. 

  • The emergence of dedicated STEAM lending libraries in each district, resourced with support from a local foundation.

  • Participation from neighboring schools and districts in the last two summer institutes.

Overall, Tough as Nails, Nimble Fingers: Developing a K-8 Coding Pathway for Kentucky Appalachia generated over 50 publications, articles, products, and presentations for researcher and practitioner audiences. The gains made in both research and practice would not have been possible without significant leadership among the participating organizations, including Floyd County Schools, Pikeville Independent Schools, Bit Source, Digital Promise, ThroughlinesEdu, South Fayette Township School District and AccelerateKY. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/27/2025
Modified by: Emi Iwatani

Key to these high-level accomplishments were numerous intermediary activities and accomplishments, established through close collaborations between teachers, researchers and broader community members. These include but are not limited to:




An operational definition of computational thinking competencies that aligns with district instructional aspirations and KY standards, and is strategically distinguished from domain-general goals such as deeper learning.

Overall, Tough as Nails, Nimble Fingers: Developing a K-8 Coding Pathway for Kentucky Appalachia generated over 50 publications, articles, products, and presentations for researcher and practitioner audiences.
